replies.commentBody:
Sure, yes, absolutely. How? You can get Trump, but then you get Pence. If you manage to get Pence then you get Ryan. If for some reason Ryan is out, then you get Hatch. Then Tillerson. Mnuchin. Mattis. Sessions (Ha!). Zinke. Ross. Price. Carson (yikes almighty). DeVoss (double and triple yikes).

So be very careful what you wish for.

In the end of all this - if we survive it - we will have to bolster the constitution to delineate what happens when an election is stolen to have a mechanism that would yank out by the roots every last bit of the treasonous cancer from the executive branch. And THEN how to install a legitimate administration. Currently this is not a process that exists. We may end up finding out what it means to fight a civil war in the 21st century.

Sessions did not lie under oath to Congress. He spoke to the Russian ambassador under his authority as a Senator. Not as a surrogate for the Trump campaign, which is what Franken asked him in his confirmation hearings. He answered the question asked to him truthfully.

comments.commentBody: With Sessions lying under oath to Congress over Russian meetings, with Manafort & Flynn up to their eyeballs in this Russia mess- yes, Trump is beyond corrupt in the RussiaGate fiasco. This administration will soon go down and will be remembered as the biggest joke ever played on America. Real patriots must act to throw them out, prosecute them and restore some respect to the White House!

Fortunately, 3 loyal American officials that care about our nation's interests requested anonymity in discussing classified intelligence. So who needs to be investigated? Hum.....

replies.commentBody:
@Michael Singer

I think the GOP members of Congress (both House and Senate) - assuming they don't rather instantaneously change their approach - will deserve their future place in history - if that ruins the GOP, that's their own fault.

If I might provide an historical comparison: Charles Lindbergh and his outright bigotry coupled with his support of Hitler and the Nazis wound-up more than offsetting his earlier achievements; we're 80 years removed from that and I'd bet any amount of money that history's verdict will never change.

On the related subject of Trump, his refusal to release his tax returns and the GOP House seemingly letting him off the hook: the release of tax returns by candidates and whoever is elected President dates back as a tradition to Nixon (his famous "I am not a crook" speech) - problem for Nixon was that he WAS a crook and would have been charged with tax evasion had he not (after his resignation) paid the IRS what he owed; it was President Ford who in one of his first acts as POTUS voluntarily released ALL of his tax returns to prove he was squeaky clean (and he was) to counter criticism that he shouldn't have pardoned Nixon.

comments.commentBody: Ever since the plank in the RNC platform last summer forbidding the US from arming the democratic government of Ukraine, evidence has been accumulating that we have indeed been dealing with a cabal of traitors, either "useful idiots," or outright Putin puppets.  Our country is at its most vulnerable point in our history.  Republicans will have to proceed with great caution, with great national devotion, lest they be branded as the party of treason, a moniker that could last for generations.  Unfortunately, it seems highly unlikely that they will come to the aid of their country.

So if Sessions has "no idea what this allegation is about”, how can he be so sure it is false???

replies.commentBody:
It's not about what you think ("I don't see any thing wrong in establishing bi-lateral or multi-lateral contacts"). It's about our laws and traditions. Flynn had contact with Russia while he was a regular citizen (against the law), and told them that the Trump administration wouldn't impose sanctions. Sessions apparently lied (perjury), also against the law.

Again, it's not about what you think or how you think it should be.

Here is what we know. The Russians hacked the DNC and leaked e-mails to WiKi leaks in order to influence the U.S. election. Trumps campaign manager (Manafort) had to resign when it was discovered he had connections with Ukraine's Russian Puppet. Trump has repeatedly praised Putin and when confronted by O'Reilly with regard to his brutality replied that the U.S. was not innocent. Trump's National Security advisor was forced to resign because he lied about discussing sanctions with the Russian Ambassador. Trump's attorney general lied in his conformation hearing about contact with Russian officials while he was a member of the Trump campaign team. Now that is what we know to be true. Curious? If it was all perfectly innocent why would they lie? I wonder what we don't know?

comments.commentBody: I don't see any thing wrong in establishing bi-lateral or multi-lateral contacts between or among parties whether in a friendly or in an adversarial context. They include contacts at individual, institutional or national-political levels. The caveat should be to make sure that there hasn't been any conspiratorial, espionage or anti-national activity leading to a short or long term threat to national security. Only until a couple of days ago, the USA had a "back-channel" communication open with North Korea, DT srapped. At the height of the Cold War, Gorbachev and Reagan had agreed to establish a "Hotline." The ways to dialogue must stay open in all circumstances. That's the definition of diplomacy. In the current context, the big questions are what have been the nature and the objectives of the contacts between the Russians on the one hand and Trump or people around him, on the other. What is that they are trying to achieve? Do the Trumps have business interest in Russia, or do the Russians have incriminating evidence against Trump -- a bomb waiting to explode ? What did Michael Flynn or Jeff Sessions talk about with the Russians? In a friendly, non-formal contexts also when the big shots (from all parts of the world) meet, they do talk about governments and the possible changes in the administrations. From that angle what Flynn or Sessions did don't appear to be sinister leading to any national security compromise. It's the agenda -- overt and/or covert -- that should matter.

"Mr. Trump has accused the Obama administration of hyping the Russia story line as a way to discredit his new administration."

It's much worse than that. Russia is 'our' enemy and no commander-in-chief is permitted to think otherwise, much less be neutral towards Russia and much less still to have friendly relations with Russia.

Even though Russia is only 1/2 the US population and 1/6 NATO's population, and even though Russia's GDP is only 2 trillion versus 36 trilllion for NATO, Russia is a threat and 'our' enemy. If Trump so much as dares to suggest they aren't, his Cabinet (or Congress) will eventually remove him. Members of the Cabinet who might resist, must be removed.

The short term reason for this is NATO/Pentagon 'jobs'. The long term result will be war and no one knows how that will end.

Russia population (2013) 143 million
NATO population (CIA) 906 million
Russia GDP (2013) 2 trillion (USD)
NATO GDP (CIA) 36 trillion (USD)

With numbers like these, Russia would not dare attack NATO - unless and until they are provoked too far. Once that happens, Putin and Russia will likely do whatever is necessary to avoid (or whatever is not as bad as) what happened to Gadaffi and Libya at the hands (and bombs) of NATO.
It's pretty clear this was a collaborative effort involving the GOP in sedition and treason at the highest levels. Let's bring back hanging.

replies.commentBody: Sara, as I read the comments on this article I too wonder if there wasn't some dog whistle (or email or text) sent to Trump fans.  Talk about a lot of heat and no light!

comments.commentBody:
Paul Krugman has repeatedly said that when anything nefarious is uncovered regarding the Trump administration, Republicans and their supporters would blame Obama. His prescient words are becoming real as evidenced by some comments here blaming Obama (and the NY Times).

As so many of the Obama/NY Times blaming comments are curiously similar, shallow and without merit, I have to ask: did Fox/Breitbart issue a talking points memo and call to "comment" on NY Times articles?
Let's see, Obama let the Russians hack our election and did nothing about it!   No, they couldn't let the blame fall on Obama, so they "preserved" the data, to try to blackmail Republicans later.

I can't get all worked up about Sessions having a meeting with a Russian official, but he's the worst possible pick for attorney general, so I hope there's sufficient evidence  linking him to Russian hacking to get him out of the job.

Oh dear, oh dear, oh dear, oh dear - This is not a good thing........

"The concerns about the contacts were cemented by a series of phone calls between Mr. Kislyak and Michael T. Flynn, who had been poised to become Mr. Trump’s national security adviser. The calls began on Dec. 29, shortly after Mr. Kislyak was summoned to the State Department and informed that, in retaliation for Russian election meddling, the United States was expelling 35 suspected Russian intelligence operatives and imposing other sanctions. Mr. Kislyak was irate and threatened a forceful Russia response, according to people familiar with the exchange.
But a day later, Mr. Putin said his government would not retaliate, prompting a Twitter post from Mr. Trump praising the Russian president — and puzzling Obama White House officials.
On Jan. 2, administration officials learned that Mr. Kislyak — after leaving the State Department meeting — called Mr. Flynn, and that the two talked multiple times in the 36 hours that followed. American intelligence agencies routinely wiretap the phones of Russian diplomats, and transcripts of the calls showed that Mr. Flynn urged the Russians not to respond, saying relations would improve once Mr. Trump was in office, according to multiple current and former officials."

Sessions has to go because he is not honest.

Aside from Trump officials' lack of character, this entire episode underscores the naivete of the Trump administration - Russia has systematically compromised the Trump officials.
